<div class="col2"> 

^10^ *ȝbd 3 ȝḫ.t sw 25  *  
*ḥb Šw zȝ-Rʿ   *  
*zȝỉ ỉʿỉ m hrw pn  *  
      
*ʿq r sḥ ỉmn   *  
*nty ỉw rn=f r ʿḥ  *  
*šzp sỉȝ.t wrḥ  *  
*ỉr(.t) m kȝr šps n ẖnmw  *  
*m s.t wr.t  *  
      
*ḥr-sȝ ḥn.t rwhȝ  *  
*ỉr(.t) ỉrw n sḫʿ nṯr pn  *  
*spr r ḏȝ(ḏȝ.t)  *  
*p(ȝ) ẖry-ḥb ḥry-tp  *  
*(ḥr) nỉs dwȝ.w (r)-ḥȝ.t=f  *  
      
*sṯȝ r-ẖnw   *  
*ḥtp ḥr s.t=f wr.t  *  
   
^10^ III Akhet day 25 ([Hathor 25](https://bookdown.org/shemanefer/Esna2/calendar-i-55.html#hathor-25) ):  
Festival of Shu, Son of Re.  
After-dinner (ritual)[^fn-343-1] on this day.  
  
Enter the remote chapel,  
the name of which is 'The Palace.'[^fn-343-0]  
Receive fringed-cloth, anointing,  
performed in the august shrine of Khnum  
on the Great Throne.  
  
After the evening service,  
perform the rite of processing this god,  
arrive at the tribune;  
the Chief Lector Priest[^fn-343-2]  
recites hymns before him.  
  
Return back inside,  
rest upon the Great Throne.  

</div>

[^fn-343-0]: ![](./images/343_10.png){width=4%} - For this abbreviated spelling of *ʿḥ*, "palace", see @sauneron-61, p. 231.
[^fn-343-1]: For this term, see primarily @sauneron-mdaik, p. 276, n. (e). 
[^fn-343-2]: ![](./images/343_10_a.png){width=14%} - Note the spelling with *ỉb* instead of *tp*, which also occurs in [Esna 346], 21. Compare a non-etymological spelling in a Demotic hymn: @hoffmann-wien, p. 220. Similar alternation between *ḥr.t-tp* and *ḥr.t-ỉb*, "uraeus", most likely for phonetic reasons, occurs more frequently at Esna and elsewhere: @goyon-notes, pp. 50-53.

<div class="col2">

*Ḥr ỉỉ(.w) r nỉw.t=f  *  
*ḏ(d)=f n Ḏḥwty  *  
*sw 25 pn pr=f m 3-nw ȝḫ.t  *  
*ỉnr ḥr wnm [ỉt]-bd.t  *  
    
*ỉr* ^11^ *n=k ỉs  *  
*ḫȝʿ.tw t  *  
*r ḥts m rqḥ wr  *  
*ḥsb n=k ḫpr ỉm=f  *  
*r rdỉ(.t) ḥtp.w-nṯr n nṯr.w  *  
*ʿnḫ n pʿ.t rḫy.t  *  
      
*ỉr ỉỉ=sn  *  
*ḥʿpỉ r ỉwḥ ȝḫ.t  *  
*m-ḫt=f  *  
     
*wn.ỉn Ḏḥwty ḥr ỉr(.t) mỉt.t  *  
  
Horus comes to his city,  
saying to Thoth:  
'This Day 25 has come forth in III Akhet:  
the worm is eating the grain.  
  
'May you ^11^ act, moreover,  
so one leaves aside bread,  
to be mummified for Rekeh-Wer;  
then, monitor what comes forth from it  
in order to give offerings to the gods,[^fn-343-5]  
and life to nobles and commoners.[^fn-343-6]  
  
'Now when they arrive,  
the Inundation will flood the field  
after him.'  
  
Then Thoth acted accordingly.  

</div>

[^fn-343-5]: As noted by @sauneron-5, p. 40, n. 3, this ritual act resembles the more famous practice of making grain Osirises during the subsequent month of Khoiak, even if the dates are different here.
[^fn-343-6]: ![](./images/343_11.png){width=16%} - Presumably the final man is a determinative to *rḫy.t*, "commoners", but it might conceivably be an ideogram for *ḥnmm.t*, "sunfolk", since other texts at Esna refer to all three classes of humanity. The star sign before the *rḫy.t*-bird is a fossil from ubiquitous group writings of *dwȝ-rḫy.t*, similar to the "signes parasites" collected by @sauneron-8, pp. 89-90.
